input: Anne is furry. Bob is furry. Fiona is nice. Fiona is red. Gary is blue. Gary is nice. Gary is not young. All white things are young. Red, white things are blue. If something is furry then it is white. If something is red and blue then it is round. If Bob is nice and Bob is white then Bob is round. All white things are red. Round, blue things are not nice. If Fiona is young then Fiona is nice. If Fiona is not blue then Fiona is nice. Question: Anne is nice.?
output:
universe u

constant obj : Type u

constant Anne : obj
constant Bob : obj
constant Fiona : obj
constant Gary : obj

constant Furry : obj → Prop
constant Nice : obj → Prop
constant Red : obj → Prop
constant Blue : obj → Prop
constant Young : obj → Prop
constant White : obj → Prop
constant Round : obj → Prop

axiom T1 : Furry Anne
axiom T2 : Furry Bob
axiom T3 : Nice Fiona
axiom T4 : Red Fiona
axiom T5 : Blue Gary
axiom T6 : Nice Gary
axiom T7 : ¬ Young Gary

axiom R1 : ∀ x : obj, White x → Young x
axiom R2 : ∀ x : obj, Red x ∧ White x → Blue x
axiom R3 : ∀ x : obj, Furry x → White x
axiom R4 : ∀ x : obj, Red x ∧ Blue x → Round x
axiom R5 : Nice Bob ∧ White Bob → Round Bob
axiom R6 : ∀ x : obj, White x → Red x
axiom R7 : ∀ x : obj, Round x ∧ Blue x → ¬ Nice x
axiom R8 : Young Fiona → Nice Fiona
axiom R9 : ¬ Blue Fiona → Nice Fiona

theorem anne_is_nice : Nice Anne :=
begin
  sorry
end

-- Looks like it cannot be proven in Lean.
-- So let's try to prove the negation of the theorem, which is Anne is not nice

theorem not_anne_is_nice : ¬ Nice Anne :=
begin
  intro H,
  apply R7 Anne,
  split,
  apply R4,
  split,
  apply R6,
  apply R3,
  exact T1,
  exact T5,
  exact H,
end

-- It can be proven in Lean. So
-- The answer is False
